intro: Lappula redowskii var. occidentalis, commonly known as western lappula, is a flowering plant native to western North America. It is a member of the family Chenopdiaceae, characterized by its succulent, fleshy leaves and small, clustered flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, disturbed soils and is often found in prairies and along roadsides. Its leaves are usually blue-green in color, and the flowers are pale green to yellow, often with a distinctive central stripe. It is an annual or biennial plant that plays a role in stabilizing soil in arid environments.
